snippet: In a 5-4 ruling that split the Supreme Court’s liberal and conservative members, the justices said that towns may start their sessions with sectarian prayers.
abstract: Supreme Court rules that the Constitution allows town boards to start their sessions with sectarian prayers, major decision on the role of religion in government; 5-to-4 vote divides court's more conservative members from its liberal ones, and their combative opinions reflect very different views of role of faith in public life, in contemporary society and in the founding of the Republic; at center of issue were public meetings in Greece, NY.
lead_paragraph: In a 5-4 ruling that split the Supreme Court’s liberal and conservative members, the justices said that towns may start their sessions with sectarian prayers.

headline.main: Town Meetings Can Have Prayer, Justices Decide
headline.print_headline: Town Meetings Can Have Prayer, Justices Decide
